bio: Ian Kittichai is a Thai chef, restaurateur, cookbook author and television host. He is known for his modern take on traditional Thai cuisine, using international techniques and ingredients. He has worked in many prestigious restaurants around the world, including the Mandarin Oriental Bangkok, Nobu in New York, and Spoon in Hong Kong. He currently owns and operates his own restaurants in Thailand and around the world.
name: Pad Thai
details: ***Ingredients: Pad Thai sauce is made typically with these four basic ingredients: tamarind, sugar, rice vinegar, and fish sauce. Soak the rice noodles in hot water until al dente. ***Method: Whisk together Pad Thai Sauce in a bowl.Prep the protein and vegetables.Whisk the eggs in a bowl.Stir-fry the Pad Thai all together!
details1: ***Ingredients: pound large shrimp, peeled and deveined, quarts water, tablespoons salt, ears of corn, in their husks,medium cloves garlic, peeled and minced, 3/4 cup plain roasted peanuts. ***Method: Put the water and the salt in a large pot and bring to a boil. Microwave corn on high heat for 4 minutes. Place the garlic, peanuts, chili(es), and dried shrimp (if using) in a heavy-duty zipper-lock bag.Add tomatoes and green beans to the peanut bag; seal the bag.Zest one lime and add the zest to the mixing bowl. Juice the zested lime and add the juice to the mixing bowl as well.Add the sugar and fish sauce to the mixing bowl. Toss the salad and adjust the taste to your liking with additional lime juice, fish sauce, or sugar. Serve immediately or cover bowl tightly with plastic wrap and keep it refrigerated for no more than one hour before serving.
details2: ***Ingredients: The beef, Galangal, Dried Chillies, Lemongrass, Coconut Milk. Method: Heat the curry paste with the onion, garlic, ginger, and spices. Whisk in the coconut milk, potatoes, fish sauce, peanut butter, and salt.***Method: Add the carrots and potatoes.Let simmer, then stir in the chicken. Simmer for 10 to 12 minutes.Remove the pot from the heat, then zest and juice the lime into it. Serve with chopped peanuts and cilantro. DIG IN!

bio: David Thompson is an Australian chef and author known for his expertise in Thai cuisine. He has spent over 30 years studying and cooking Thai food, including working in some of Thailand's most prestigious restaurants. He has published several cookbooks on Thai cuisine, including the award-winning 'Thai Food'. He currently runs his own restaurant, Aaharn, in Hong Kong.
name: Tom Kha Gai
details: ***Ingredients:1 cup (240ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock, One 4-inch piece fresh galangal (50g), peeled, 2 2/3 cups (620ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock 3 stalks lemongrass, bottom 7 inches only, outer leaves discarded, tender core cut on a bias into 2-inch lengths (about 120g),  shallots (40g), peeled and roughly smashed in a mortar and pestle. ***Method:  Pour galangal stock through a fine-mesh strainer into saucepan, pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible before discarding the fiber. Stir in makrut lime leaves, fresh chiles, and coconut cream then remove from heat. Stir in lime juice and remaining fish sauce.To serve, divide between warmed soup bowls and garnish with cilantro
details1: ***Ingredients: lbs frying boneless skinless chicken, and cut into small chunks, coconut milk, fish sauce, Laos powder, green curry paste,  fresh sweet basil leaves, fresh lime leaves,  green peas, serrano chilies. ***Method: Place your chicken, 2 cups of coconut milk, fish sauce, and laos powder in a wok or large frying pan, and bring to a boil, allowing them to boil until the chicken is cooked and tender.Remove your chicken from the pan with a slotted spoon leaving everything else behind, and put it on a plate and set aside.Allow the milk to continue boiling until it is very thick and oily. Then take your curry paste, and add it to the pan. Finally, add your basil and citrus leaves, peas and serranos, increase your heat and allow it to boil for 5 minutes. Serve immediately.
details2: ***Ingredients: 1 small papaya, 1 medium clove garlic, minced, 1 small red chile pepper, such as Thai bird, seeded and finely chopped, 2 tablespoons fish sauce, or soy sauce, 2 tablespoons vegetable oil ***Method: Gather the ingredients., Peel the green papaya., Using the largest grater you have (such as one for scalloped potatoes), grate the green fruit, rotating it as you go to avoid hitting the inner seeds., If you don't have a grater, try a method used in Thailand: First, deeply score the flesh using a large, sharp knife., Add most of the peanuts, holding some back to be used for garnish, and toss again. Serve your salad as is or as a side dish to any Thai entree. If this is your main course, try serving it with a side of sticky rice like they do in Thailand.

bio: Darin 'Dee' Limsuansub is a Thai chef and owner of the restaurant Limsuansub in Bangkok. She is known for her creative and playful approach to Thai cuisine, using unexpected ingredients and techniques to create unique and memorable dishes. She has won several awards for her cooking, including Iron Chef Thailand in 2020. She is also an advocate for using sustainable and locally sourced ingredients in her cooking.
name: Green Papaya Salad
details: ***Ingredients: 1 small papaya, 1 medium clove garlic, minced, 1 small red chile pepper, such as Thai bird, seeded and finely chopped, 2 tablespoons fish sauce, or soy sauce, 2 tablespoons vegetable oil ***Method: Gather the ingredients., Peel the green papaya., Using the largest grater you have (such as one for scalloped potatoes), grate the green fruit, rotating it as you go to avoid hitting the inner seeds., If you don't have a grater, try a method used in Thailand: First, deeply score the flesh using a large, sharp knife., Add most of the peanuts, holding some back to be used for garnish, and toss again. Serve your salad as is or as a side dish to any Thai entree. If this is your main course, try serving it with a side of sticky rice like they do in Thailand.
details1: ***Ingredients: The beef, Galangal, Dried Chillies, Lemongrass, Coconut Milk. ***Method: Heat the curry paste with the onion, garlic, ginger, and spices. Whisk in the coconut milk, potatoes, fish sauce, peanut butter, and salt. Add the carrots and potatoes.Let simmer, then stir in the chicken. Simmer for 10 to 12 minutes.Remove the pot from the heat, then zest and juice the lime into it. Serve with chopped peanuts and cilantro. DIG IN!
details2: ***Ingredients:1 cup (240ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock, One 4-inch piece fresh galangal (50g), peeled, 2 2/3 cups (620ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock 3 stalks lemongrass, bottom 7 inches only, outer leaves discarded, tender core cut on a bias into 2-inch lengths (about 120g),  shallots (40g), peeled and roughly smashed in a mortar and pestle. ***Method:  Pour galangal stock through a fine-mesh strainer into saucepan, pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible before discarding the fiber. Stir in makrut lime leaves, fresh chiles, and coconut cream then remove from heat. Stir in lime juice and remaining fish sauce.To serve, divide between warmed soup bowls and garnish with cilantro

bio: Bee Satongun is a Thai chef and co-owner of the Michelin-starred restaurant Paste in Bangkok. She is known for her dedication to traditional Thai cooking techniques and ingredients, as well as her creativity in combining different regional Thai cuisines. She has won several awards for her cooking, including Asia's 50 Best Restaurants in 2018 and 2019.
name: Massaman Curry
details: ***Ingredients: The beef, Galangal, Dried Chillies, Lemongrass, Coconut Milk. ***Method: Heat the curry paste with the onion, garlic, ginger, and spices. Whisk in the coconut milk, potatoes, fish sauce, peanut butter, and salt. Add the carrots and potatoes.Let simmer, then stir in the chicken. Simmer for 10 to 12 minutes.Remove the pot from the heat, then zest and juice the lime into it. Serve with chopped peanuts and cilantro. DIG IN!

Serve your salad as is or as a side dish to any Thai entree. If this is your main course, try serving it with a side of sticky rice like they do in Thailand.

bio: Pim Techamuanvivit is a Thai chef, food writer, and cookbook author based in San Francisco. She is known for her blog 'Chez Pim' and her cookbook 'The Foodie Handbook'. She is also a columnist for the San Francisco Chronicle and has written for several other publications. She is passionate about preserving traditional Thai cooking techniques and ingredients, while also experimenting with new flavors and techniques.
name: Pad Kra Pao
details: ***Ingredients:1 cup (240ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock, One 4-inch piece fresh galangal (50g), peeled, 2 2/3 cups (620ml) homemade or store-bought chicken stock 3 stalks lemongrass, bottom 7 inches only, outer leaves discarded, tender core cut on a bias into 2-inch lengths (about 120g),  shallots (40g), peeled and roughly smashed in a mortar and pestle. ***Method:  Pour galangal stock through a fine-mesh strainer into saucepan, pressing on solids to extract as much liquid as possible before discarding the fiber. bio: Sarinthorn Chanchaleun, also known as 'Chef Ann', is a Thai chef and co-owner of the restaurant Krok in Bangkok. She is known for her creative and innovative approach to Thai cuisine, using modern techniques and ingredients while still honoring traditional Thai flavors. She has worked in several Michelin-starred restaurants in Europe and Asia, including The Ledbury in London and Gaggan in Bangkok. She has also won several awards for her cooking, including Iron Chef Thailand in 2016.
name: Khao Soi
details: ***Ingredients: large dried New Mexico or guajillo chiles, stemmed, halved, seeded medium shallots, halved,garlic cloves, ginger, peeled, sliced, cup chopped cilantro stems ***Method: Place chiles in a small heatproof bowl, add boiling water to cover, and let soak until softened, 25–30 minutes. Drain chiles, reserving soaking liquid. Purée chiles, shallots, garlic, ginger, cilantro stems, coriander, turmeric, curry powder, and 2 Tbsp. soaking liquid in a food processor, adding more soaking liquid by tablespoonfuls, if needed, until smooth. Heat oil in a large heavy pot over medium heat. Add khao soi paste; cook, stirring constantly, until slightly darkened, 4–6 minutes. Add coconut milk and broth. Bring to a boil; add chicken. Reduce heat and simmer until chicken is fork-tender, 20–25 minutes. Transfer chicken to a plate. Let cool slightly; shred meat. Meanwhile, cook noodles according to package directions. Add chicken, 3 Tbsp. fish sauce, and sugar to soup. Season with salt or more fish sauce, if needed. Divide soup and noodles among bowls and serve with toppings.
details1: ***Ingredients: lbs frying boneless skinless chicken, and cut into small chunks, coconut milk, fish sauce, Laos powder, green curry paste,  fresh sweet basil leaves, fresh lime leaves,  green peas, serrano chilies. ***Method: Place your chicken, 2 cups of coconut milk, fish sauce, and laos powder in a wok or large frying pan, and bring to a boil, allowing them to boil until the chicken is cooked and tender.Remove your chicken from the pan with a slotted spoon leaving everything else behind, and put it on a plate and set aside.Allow the milk to continue boiling until it is very thick and oily. Then take your curry paste, and add it to the pan. Finally, add your basil and citrus leaves, peas and serranos, increase your heat and allow it to boil for 5 minutes. Serve immediately.
